scenario: Mobile app engagement improvement from 30% D1 retention to 50% target
description: Golden example for oblique strategies applied to mobile engagement problem

inputs.problem_statement: Increase mobile app D1 retention from 30% to 50% while maintaining user satisfaction scores
creative_constraints: No dark patterns or manipulative tactics
inputs.success_criteria: 8-10 oblique strategies, diverse constraint generation, enables creative synthesis

ideas.description: Instead of teaching users features upfront, hide all advanced features and only reveal them when users actively express frustration or curiosity. Track user behavior patterns to identify the exact moment they need a feature, then introduce it contextually with celebration.

dimensions.mechanism: Behavior-triggered progressive disclosure with celebration moments
dimensions.experience: Mystery box interface that reveals on earned discovery
dimensions.market: Power users who enjoy mastery and discovery

ideas.rationale: Oblique strategy: 'What would your closest friend do?' - Treat users like friends discovering secrets together rather than students being lectured
initial_concerns: Users might leave before discovering critical features
Requires sophisticated behavior analytics
Risk of feeling patronizing if not executed well

ideas.description: Create 'vulnerability moments' where users can share struggles, setbacks, or authentic experiences within the app. These moments are ephemeral (24h) and create intimate micro-communities. Success is measured by authenticity, not engagement metrics.

dimensions.mechanism: Ephemeral authentic sharing with no metrics visible
dimensions.experience: Private safe space for vulnerability and connection
dimensions.market: Users seeking authentic connection over performative social

ideas.rationale: Oblique strategy: 'Honor thy error as a hidden intention' - Design for failure and authenticity, not just success stories
initial_concerns: Moderation complexity for sensitive content
Risk of negativity spiral without careful design
Privacy implications of vulnerable sharing

ideas.description: Design micro-interactions that create open loops - questions without immediate answers, partial reveals, intentional ambiguity. Users return not for notifications but because their curiosity was genuinely sparked. Loops resolve on user-driven schedules, not system timers.

dimensions.market: Curious users who enjoy exploration and puzzle-solving

ideas.rationale: Oblique strategy: 'Use an old idea' - Apply Zeigarnik effect (incomplete tasks stay in memory) but ethically through genuine curiosity, not manufactured urgency
initial_concerns: Difficult to balance curiosity vs. frustration
Requires exceptional content and pacing
May not work for utility-focused apps

ideas.description: Remove all visible metrics (likes, followers, streaks) and replace with qualitative reflection prompts. Instead of 'You have 50 followers', show 'Sarah said your post helped her today'. Shift from quantitative validation to qualitative impact.

dimensions.mechanism: Qualitative impact feedback replacing quantitative metrics
dimensions.market: Users suffering from social media anxiety and comparison fatigue

ideas.rationale: Oblique strategy: 'Look at the order in which you do things' - Reverse the typical social app logic entirely by removing the metrics-first approach
initial_concerns: Radical departure from proven engagement patterns
Users might miss traditional validation signals
Harder to demonstrate growth to stakeholders

ideas.description: Users earn the right to receive notifications by proving they value them. Start with zero notifications, then users explicitly request notification categories after using the app. Each category requires a 'contract' where users commit to engaging or losing that privilege.
ideas.rationale: Oblique strategy: 'Emphasize the flaws' - Make notification permission scarce and valuable, acknowledging that most notifications are ignored anyway
initial_concerns: Lower initial engagement without push notifications
Complex permission system might confuse users
Requires data infrastructure to track notification engagement

ideas.description: Design the best possible experience for offline mode, treating connectivity as optional luxury rather than requirement. Offline mode gets unique features, easter eggs, and capabilities that online mode lacks. Users choose offline for benefits, not just necessity.

dimensions.experience: Premium offline experience with unique capabilities
dimensions.market: Users in low-connectivity environments or seeking digital mindfulness

ideas.rationale: Oblique strategy: 'What context would look right?' - Flip the constraint (offline limitation) into an opportunity for unique value
initial_concerns: Complex sync conflict resolution
Risk of fragmenting user experience between modes
Requires robust local storage and state management

ideas.description: Create moments that celebrate user failures, abandoned attempts, and imperfect progress. When users quit a task, return to celebrate the attempt. Track 'tries' not 'completions'. Make failure data visible and valuable instead of hidden and shameful.

dimensions.mechanism: Failure tracking with positive reinforcement systems
dimensions.experience: Progress visualization celebrating attempts over outcomes
dimensions.market: Learning-focused users and growth mindset audiences

ideas.rationale: Oblique strategy: 'Accept advice' then invert it - Traditional apps hide failures; we make them first-class citizens
initial_concerns: Risk of normalizing giving up
Requires careful messaging to avoid demotivation
May conflict with achievement-oriented users

ideas.description: App interface and features transform based on time of day and user energy patterns. Morning version is minimal and focused, evening version is richer and exploratory. System learns individual chronotypes and adapts automatically. Same app, different personalities.

dimensions.mechanism: Chronotype-aware adaptive interface with machine learning
dimensions.experience: Context-shifting UI based on circadian rhythms
dimensions.market: Health-conscious users and productivity optimization enthusiasts

ideas.rationale: Oblique strategy: 'Work at a different speed' - Match app pace to user's natural rhythms instead of constant always-on engagement
initial_concerns: Complex to build multiple interface modes
Privacy concerns with behavioral tracking
Users might be confused by changing interfaces

ideas.description: Every piece of content in the app is collaboratively created by multiple users in asynchronous creation sessions. No solo posts - everything is a collaboration, even if just adding a single word or emoji. Creates ownership and return visits to see how collaboration evolved.

dimensions.experience: Collaborative canvas with version history and attribution
dimensions.market: Creative communities and collaborative team spaces

ideas.rationale: Oblique strategy: 'Ask people to work against their better judgement' - Force collaboration when solo posting is easier, creating friction that builds community
initial_concerns: Coordination overhead for simple actions
Quality control with multiple contributors
Attribution and ownership conflicts

ideas.description: App is intentionally unavailable during certain hours (e.g., 10pm-6am) with beautiful 'closed' screens that encourage rest and reflection. Users can override but must write a brief reflection on why. System learns patterns and suggests personalized downtime.

dimensions.experience: Boundaries-first design with mindful override process
dimensions.market: Digital wellness advocates and users seeking healthier tech relationships

ideas.rationale: Oblique strategy: 'Abandon normal instruments' - Reject the always-available app paradigm entirely, treating unavailability as a feature
initial_concerns: Users will switch to competitor apps that are always available
Emergency access scenarios need careful design
Requires strong brand positioning to justify

metadata.context: Mobile productivity app struggling with 30% D1 retention rate. Current approach uses standard engagement tactics (streaks, notifications, social proof). Users report feeling overwhelmed and manipulated. Need to increase retention to 50% while improving user satisfaction.
constraints: No dark patterns or manipulative tactics allowed
Must work offline-first for low-connectivity users
Maximum 3 notification categories to avoid overwhelm
